text: this is what it takes to retake a city
from so-called Islamic state the scene
in Ramadi after a six-day offensive with
Iraqi soldiers leaving a ground campaign
supported by airstrikes from the
coalition forces Iraqi troops fought a
battle streets by street house to house
is fighters had months to build their
defense the whole city center was
booby-trapped but the security forces
have now forced the jihadists to abandon
their stronghold the former provincial
government compound from where they
organized their resistance taking
control of this position is key to
retaking Ramadi sporadic fighting
continues in the neighborhood but Iraqi
forces are confidence they now have the
upper hand our operations that started a
few days ago so a rough day today for
the Armed Forces and counterterrorism
forces but we gained control of our host
which is the key to enter the
governmental square and this is what
Iraqis soldiers want to forget when they
abandoned the city - Islamic state
fighters pictures of their hasty retreat
were an embarrassment for the country
it's taken months for the security
forces to work out a plan to retake
Ramadi their first isolated the city
from all sides - cut off is militants
supply routes before this final push
this is a success in the fight against
Islamic state but it is only the start
of a battle that will get much tougher
in the north of the country
Timofey see BBC News Baghdad
